plants.description: A large, meaty tomato variety with a classic tomato flavor. Fruits can weigh up to 2 pounds.
plants.harvest_notes: Harvest when fruits are fully red but still firm. Twist gently or cut from the vine.
plants.storage_notes: Store at room temperature for best flavor. Refrigeration dulls flavor but extends shelf life.
plants.additional_notes: Indeterminate variety that will continue to produce until frost. Requires staking or caging for support.

pests.description: Large green caterpillar with white diagonal stripes and a horn-like projection on its rear.
pests.symptoms: Defoliation of upper leaves, damage to fruit, black droppings on leaves.
prevention_methods: Companion planting with dill or basil

pests.description: Small soft-bodied insects that cluster on new growth and undersides of leaves.
pests.symptoms: Curled leaves, sticky honeydew residue, stunted growth, sooty mold.

diseases.description: Fungal disease that affects tomatoes, potatoes, and other nightshade plants.
diseases.symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings (target-like appearance) on lower leaves first, then spreading upward. Leaves may yellow and drop.
treatment_methods: Remove and destroy infected plant parts
Ensure proper plant spacing for air circulation

diseases.description: Highly destructive fungal-like disease that caused the Irish Potato Famine. Can destroy entire crops in favorable conditions.
diseases.symptoms: Water-soaked spots on leaves that quickly enlarge to form purple-brown, oily blotches. White fungal growth may appear on leaf undersides in humid conditions. Stems and fruits develop dark lesions.
treatment_methods: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
Apply copper-based or specific late blight fungicides

interactions.mechanism_description: Basil repels tomato hornworm and improves tomato flavor.
Marigolds repel nematodes and other soil pests.

companion_relationships.notes: Plant marigolds around the perimeter of tomato plants.
